pros:
1. Nice working environment
2. Laid back atmosphere
3. Good benefits
cons:
1. Slow in technology development
2. Good in documentation and rules but generally each site has its own interpretation of rules, standards, checklists and methods hence it makes releasing a project confusing, complex and prone to error. 
3. Too much office politics
4. Slow in promoting in-house staff, much better to resign first and come back which is usually the way at Infineon
5. The project manager role is important but can easily be blamed for any error, delay or over budget in a project
6. Travel claims are so slow to process
7. Still trying to fix the work life balance concept , anyhow work from  home is only available for 3 days but still needs approval from boss
8. Too many meetings, the only company where there is an "alignment meeting" to a meeting, a pre-review of a review or approval meeting, the days are dotted with meetings
9. In an era to make processes faster, this company is perfecting red tape - making documentation requests, release and processing too slow (e.g. requesting for employee letter, etc)

pros: A process-oriented work environment has its pros in aspects of effectiveness (doing the right things), traceability and perhaps quality.  The company has  good learning & development program for its employees (but it also depends on the manager's decision to approve his/her employees' course applications).
cons:
On the contrary, overly process-driven may stifle efficiency (doing things in the best possible manner with the least waste of time and effort), curiosity and creativity. 
The work environment does not distinctly prevail an open and transparent culture.

review_title: Working here is like navigating a maze
pros: Quite a lot of competitors so technology and products move fast giving people great learning and collaboration opportunities. Steep learning curve allows brilliant people to really shine. Plenty of cross-site learning communities that allow you to really build your skills. Freshers have a great opportunity to gain tremendous knowledge in the first few years of working.
cons: Your daily routine consists of coming up with ways with blame someone for every small delay rather than give you time to focus on work. The blaming culture is a bit too extreme to the point that it can get sickening.  Managers will jump 10 feet in the air if there is an email asking why there is a delay. Enough to give everyone hypertension.  Very poor work life balance, you are informally expected to work round the clock including answering emails on the weekends.  Not a healthy sign when communication on email is replaced by whatsapp messages especially when you're on the way to work in the morning.

review_title: Insider Observations on Infineon global and Infineon Singapore
pros: Singapore. Initially I have the strong impression of joining one of the leading German engineering company with solid engineering process, know-how, structure etc. ... Being a German company, unless the company is facing a crisis, they try to keep people employed and avoid even pay cuts.
cons: Singapore. Being as a offshore site, it faces quite similar challenges with other MNC companies not being the HQ. Although Singapore is the APAC HQ, there is very little benefit in my mind. Unless you have fluent German, somehow there is still the language barrier. Culturally, this company's traits are "no trust in what you do" until you have proven yourself in the 'what' and 'how'. So be prepared to start off establishing these for some years. In terms of benefits, it is quite poor. No profit sharing, No stock option or RSU, very basic health insurance for only the employee (family you have to pay $1k plus every year extra). Work wise, to be brutally honest, because of the strong workers union in Germany, a lot of the workload is thrown over to offshore sites. If you compare the workload of a similar job role, my experience is doing 2x the load and 1/2 the pay. In short, offshore sites get squeezed. Another downside of the culture here, is that majority of employees (at least 80%) do not have sense of ownership of what they do and no sense of urgency. They need to have many project managers to push them and a lot of these poor project managers have to fight with other project managers for resource of up to 0.1  man months ... The rootcause of this is the appraisal system. the rating here is A (exceed) to D (do not meet(. both A and D are EXTREMELY hard to achieve. So why will employees want to put in the extra? And the poor project managers are squeezed by management for not delivering while they do not have the empowerment to set appraisals for these people. Line managers on the other hand get away by pushing responsibilities to the project manager; being the 'nice' managers to the team and pushing the 'bad guy' role to the project manager. Oh by the way, promotions are seriously RELATIONSHIP first and then others like skillset, experience and competence. So long as you are NOT a German, forget about holding senior positions or high responsibilities. I saw a case where a new hire (with master degree) with couple of years of experience is put as a project manager who is a German. Instead of giving this other other more experienced project managers in the offshore. And as expected, this project manager who has no technical hands-on skills is calling the shots on microcontrollers that are going into your BMWs, Audis, Mercedes etc. ... even the basic companies have a pantry with drinks and biscuits. Here, you have to pay using vending machines. And biscuits come one in 2 weeks and if you don't take it, it's gone.

For eg, despite  availability of flexible work arrangement,  management is quite traditional and do not actively & openly support it.

review_title: Please dont spoil your career by joining here.
pros: Generally the overall company's culture is not that bad, but mainly depends on the group which you work which matters a lot. They have on / above par medical benefits, transport facilities....etc. Pretty good laid back place.
cons:
So far in my professional career, I have never seen such a department filled with dumb and idiotic people running the analytics function. 
For people starting their careers in analytics or who have been in this area of analytics, please please dont join as this place will ruin your career. The management just knows how to play politics for example isolating key people from the projects, not involving right people in their areas of expertise, racial bias when hiring, not giving due credit for the work, appreciate your work and creativity. The whole division is known as "Little India" this is for a reason, as its filled with people from a particular race. The team is led by people who doesn't have basic knowledge about analytics, and they're the ones who conduct interviews for hiring people,so if you think the interview was easy the worse is yet to come after you join this place. The management just knows on how to beat around the bush. So whatever work you do, you will never get any due credit for your work.

If you join this place you will forget what you would have learnt previously(in your schools / work places). If you would like to learn on how to conduct politics you can do your doctorate degree in playing politics here. 

So one important thing is that when you join this place, it would be very difficult for you when you want to switch your jobs as you won't be keeping pace with current analytics trends, Henceforth getting your next job would be very very difficult.

review_title: Un-rewarding, in spite of being recognized for good work.

cons: Bad management, Poor salary compared to industry, Slow response in decision making, No room to grow. "we-do-not-care" and top-to-bottom style of management.

review_title: Slowest employee growth - very bad IT department in Bangalore
pros:
Friendly people (on the surface)

Good and defined processes for global IT infra procurement like virtual machines and servers.

Good for people who are able to show off without doing much.

Good work life balance.
cons:
Even though the work life balance tends to be good, India office's work culture is modelled to copy the German work culture. And that's what it is, a copy. It's clearly evident because it's not followed at the heart of organisation management. India office MD shows this clearly.

Too much favouritism. Others are treated just as task completors. 

Super slow career growth. You've to go through elaborate process to get a grade increase. Don't even get me started on promotion.

Slow technological innovation

HR is constantly in the mode of enforcement but not enablement. 

This is a service based company management at heart with a 'product based company' mask on face.

review_title: Run Away As Fast As You Can.
pros: Nothing much comes to mind, the 401(k) matching is pretty decent.
cons:
Everything else, from useless management to an HR department that spends all its time protecting the ridiculous decisions and incredibly poor judgement of management. 

If you have an ounce of ambition in your run away from this company as fast as you can. You won't get anywhere. All decisions have to come from Germany, all inventions have to come from Germany. The approach is that if you're not German/Austrian you have nothing constructive to contribute. 

The fact that the Americas CEO is a marketing guy who probably has never set foot in a fab tells you everything you need to know about how the parent company regards the US. 

IT management is weak, borderline criminally negligent. They are stuck in a 20th century world view. You're not every going to be allowed to work remotely here. 

Incompetent know-nothing managers who were promoted based on who they knew rather than what they knew have to micro-manage you to within an inch of your life to try to justify their existence. They can't do that if you're remote!

review_title: Experience and challenges depend on which department you're in. High job security but less competitive remuneration.
pros:
1. Good work-life balance for non/less technical roles (project managers, site planners, etc.). More technical roles such as product or process engineers are more demanding and a lot busier.
2. People oriented management. Depends on the department but overall foreign (non-Malaysian) managers and directors are humble and possess better EQ than local managers.
3. Career progression opportunities.
4. High job security.
cons:
1. Not competitive salary. Salary tends to be on the low side compared to other semiconductor manufacturing giants. Increments is although consistent but too little. 
2. Outdated system. A lot of jobs have to be done manually although there are efforts to automate some redundant tasks.
3. Uneven job distribution. A problem many will face if they work in technical roles, especially production department.
